subject: I need clarification on British pronunciations.
msgSnippet: I started creating my own phonetic alphabet a while back, and while doing some research, I ran into the Shavian Alphabet, which then lead me to the Read
messageBody:
I started creating my own phonetic alphabet a while back, and while doing some research, I ran into the Shavian Alphabet, which then lead me to the Read Alphabet. I have since been putting my efforts into learning the latter, since it is very close to what I was attempting to create. I printed out the Quikscript manual by Read, and feel pretty comfortable with my writing, although my reading is still quite slow. 


I have, however, ran into several questions, mostly regarding the differences in Read's accent (what I view as the official Quikscript accent) and my own American accent (I have the accent which is used by the majority of Americans; the same that is used in almost every American movie). If I could hear recordings of Read's voice, I believe that most of my questions could be answered. More writing from Read himself in Quikscript might also be enlightening. The problem that I have is that I have no idea whether or not I am pronouncing the sample words given for the letters as Read did, and since I am not native to his accent, I don't know where to start studying, since I'm sure there are various British accents. I suppose I could just continue on pronouncing the letters the way I think they sound, and it will work great for personal use, but if this alphabet is ever to be accurately adapted to most or all english accents, we need some consistency, rather than personal interpretation of a letter's sound. So, following are my questions. All sample words and examples I use are found in the official Quikscript manual.


1. Letter # 26 It

Initially, I thought this letter makes the sound Americans use in such words as igloo, him, spirit. Read acknowledges this sound I described when he wrote that his pronunciation of the word "been" sounds different from the American pronunciation of the same word. He spelled it as "bin" to signify the use of this sound by Americans. I am not sure he represents this sound in his alphabet, however. He uses letter 26 (by the way, if these letters have accepted names, I would love to know) to spell the words tin, it, in, which work with my understanding of the letter's sound, but then it is also used in busy, Mary, writing, which cause a  problem. Americans pronounce these words with an Eeeeee sound, as in bee, enough, eat, bleed, which sound I believe to be represented by letter 27. Does this letter in fact make the American sound I described (according to Read's intended accent), or does it make a different sound? If it does make a different sound, what letter do I use for my pronunciation of these words? 


2. Letters # 32 Ah, #33 Awe, #34 Ox 

At first, I could make no distinction between these three, but now I do believe I can tell a slight difference in 33. I am still at a loss to hear any difference at all between 32 and 34. I am assuming that Read wouldn't create multiple letters for the same sound, so in his accent, obviously there is a noticeable difference, which an American can't hear in our pronunciation of words he uses these letters in within the manual. So, which of the letters comes closer to the sound Americans make in words like cough, not, calm? Does 33 make the sound which Americans say in "The Titanic got a hole in her hull, as she pulled away from the iceburg"?


3. Letters #21 Ing

For the life of me, I can't figure out this letter! At first I thought it made the full "ing" sound (Americans pronounce this like eeeeeng, with an audible g), but that theory got shot down with words Read used like Anger, hunger, ink, uncle; obviously it does not make the American "ing" sound. Then I thought that it made the "ng" sound, with an audible "g". That didn't hold up either, when I found words with this letter like ink,anchor, uncle, and think. Then I thought, maybe it makes the "in" sound (sounds like eeeeen to Americans). Wrong again. It doesn't make that sound in the words anger, hunger, anchor, or uncle. Does this letter just make an "n" sound, like letter # 23? if so, what is the difference between the two? The only pattern I can find with this letter is that it is always followed by the G or K sound; which makes it like the orthodox letter "Q"; a letter which must always be paired up with the letter "U" to be correctly written, which is a poor decision to include in an improved alphabet. Unless there is some pronunciation of this letter I can't hear, please explain to my why this letter is necessary. I don't even use it, and I am able to write all the words with the letter # 23 instead, and it works perfectly.


4. Combination letters

The letter # 25 Roe combines with several of the vowels, and my accent agrees with half of the combos. With an American accent, the word "air" should be written 28-25 instead of the given 29-25. Read writes the word "marry" with 30-25, which combo isn't used with my accent. If I understand the correct pronunciation of letter 36 Utter, then the combo of 36-25 is not correct in words such as butter, early, girl, murder. When the two letters are pronounced individually in quick succession, it does not make the necessary sound for the above words, with my accent. 36-25 comes close, as well as 39-25, but neither do the job properly. I think this sound needs a completely new letter; I just use the letter 25 turned backwards to signify this sound in my own writing. If I am wrong, please let me know why. Also, I believe that letters 35 OY, and 37 OUt are simply combination sound as well, and are perhaps unnecessary letters as a result. I think that #35 is a combo of 33 & 17. Is there any difference in the word "boy" if it is spelled 2-33-17 or 2-35? I think #37 is a combo of 30 & 38. Is there any difference in the word "cow" if it is spelled 5-30-38 or 5-37? Please explain the differences.


To end, I am not trying to criticize Read's wonderful alphabet, I simply want understanding, so I can use it properly. I hope to get answers from those who are natural speakers of the two accents mentioned. Thank you!
